snippet: In Type 2 diabetics, the pancreas’s beta cells work harder to produce insulin, and it was believed they eventually died. Now research in mice suggests they may be reverting to a precursor state.
abstract: Scientists have long struggled to understand why beta cells in the pancreas eventually lose their ability to produce insulin in Type 2 diabetics; Columbia University study in journal Cell suggests that when mice are subjected to physiological stress, their beta cells can revert to an earlier developmental state in which they no longer produce the hormone.
lead_paragraph: In Type 2 diabetics, the pancreas’s beta cells work harder to produce insulin, and it was believed they eventually died. Now research in mice suggests they may be reverting to a precursor state.

headline.seo: Under Stress, Insulin-Making Cells Revert to Nascent State
headline.main: High Stress Can Make Insulin Cells Regress
